utterances: SHULTZ: Yeah, the thing that's really wild for me, though, is I remember when I was younger even kind of having a pretty melancholy disposition.
And I don't know if I ever would've thought of, like, life being so fruitful.
SHULTZ: We grew up with not much money, and we had four boys in our family, and we all stayed in the same room, so...
I know that at one point you lived with your grandparents after your parents were divorced.
I mean, it sounds like there was a lot of hardship in your youth.
Did you have to lean on each other?
I mean, was there times that you really needed the support of one another?
SHULTZ: I think we definitely helped each other through a lot of hard times.
I mean, you talk about having a kind of melancholy, and there's been a lot of loss in your lives since your last album.
How does that come out in the music?
SHULTZ: I think in a lot of different ways.
I mean, we went through an extremely rough point where we lost my wife's father.
SHULTZ: I think that subconsciously affects everything about you and for some reason led us down the road to even what kind of instrumentation that we put into the songs.
Can you give us an example of the instrumentation being a little different on one of these songs than then maybe it might have been had things gone differently in the last few years?
SHULTZ: ""Tokyo Smoke"" would be a really good one to hear.
Hand me down with the crooked back.
Boy, you don't know where you're at.
SHULTZ: In this track, there's definitely a big presence of that kind of, like, horror film influence as well as this kind of bizarre darkness.
It's not, like, a sad darkness, but it's more of almost, like, this - frustrated, angry.
Yeah, this is not, like, a lay-on-your-bed-and-cry.
My old unfaithful friend, stick and move.
Don't be surprised if you can't stay between the lines.
But on this album, the loss comes across in a lot of different colors.
Like, the final track, ""Goodbye,"" is so heartbreaking.
It may express grief, but it expresses grief in an entirely different way from most of the other songs on the album.
(Singing) A pretty bird, my favorite lullaby, how'd I become the thorn in your side?
All your laughter turned into a cry.
I don't know why this keeps standing out to me.
But one thing that has stood out to me is the presence of joy within sadness and grief.
And there's the many different shifts within the grieving process as well.
When you hear or perform this song now, does it take you back to that emotional place, or are you able to sort of be like, OK, clocking in for work, going to perform this song?
SHULTZ: It's actually kind of odd.
We recently lost one of our best friends, Tiger Merritt from a band called Morning Teleportation.
SHULTZ: And we had planned this song to be released months...
SHULTZ: Months before now, yes, yeah.
SHULTZ: ...Before, and it happened to be released the day after his funeral.
SHULTZ: And the song just took on a whole different meaning for me.
There are real moments of hope on this album, though, like the song The War Is Over.
So when you sing the war is over; love's already won, what's it a war against?
I think many people walk around with a sense of guilt just for existing.
And the reality of life is we're on a planet within a solar system that is traveling so many miles per hour around a massive ball of gas, and here life is.
So our mere existence is validation.
I think the war is already over.
You can hide your heart inside a man-made house.
You can build your walls, build them to the sky.
One day you will find love was on both sides.
You two have come so far from the kids who dug a drum kit out of a dumpster in Kentucky.

But when I think about the amount of pain and loss and grief that you've suffered in the last few years, I wonder whether you find yourselves as brothers still leaning on each other in a way similar to what you had to do to get through your difficult childhood.
Especially this last few months, I feel like we've really been leaning on each other.
SHULTZ: I think more now than ever...
And I think we kind of rediscover that on every record that we make.
SHULTZ: I actually just teared up.
